Award.AwardTitle: CAREER: Smooth Group Actions - Persistence and Prevalence of Chaotic Behavior
Award.AbstractNarration:
This project will address several important questions concerning higher-rank smooth group actions: characterization of actions that cannot be obtained from classical dynamical systems (diffeomorphisms and flows) via classical constructions; the prevalence of chaotic behavior in the space of partially hyperbolic higher-rank actions; the extent to which global hypoellipticity of the sublaplacian for conservative actions gives a general set-up for stability under perturbations; the search for new nonalgebraic examples of weakly rigid higher-rank actions. The creation of a bridge between findings on algebraic higher-rank actions that rely on analytic tools and the more dynamical approach used for general smooth actions is crucial for an improved understanding of rigidity phenomena. For algebraic higher-rank actions, the project will study connections between cohomological obstructions obtained geometrically and those obtained analytically from the induced action on representations. Part of the strategy is to work towards answering these questions by focusing on representative examples. The principal investigator's main interest is in actions by groups that have higher rank but that lack rich geometric or algebraic structure (e.g., abelian groups, nilpotent groups, solvable groups).

Persistence of dynamics under perturbations is an old question in science. We completely understand the future and the past only for sufficiently simple systems, which are merely approximations of observed phenomena. Chaotic behavior was initially considered to be a pathology. However, it turns out to be a source of stability. Studies showing that it is a healthy heartbeat that demonstrates the presence of chaos are not surprising, provided that one accepts the fact that nature prefers stability. For systems that fall under the heading "group actions" the relation between chaos and stability is even more dramatic: weaker chaotic behavior tends to imply stronger stability for the system. Group actions can be thought of as systems with multidimensional time. As such, they are useful models in biology (neural networks), chemistry (quasi-crystals), and computer science (multidimensional data storage). In particular models, chaos appears in different guises. It is a goal of this project to explore conditions under which systems with diverse chaotic behavior preserve their dynamical properties under perturbations. This topic is especially amenable to introducing students to research in the area of dynamical systems. Through the study of simple models, students can develop intuition, learn what the open problems are, and make their own contribution to the actual research by performing specific computations. This is the rationale for the project's outreach component, which is aimed at high-school girls and the goal of which is to introduce mathematical research and insights into academic careers to female students at an early stage in their intellectual development.

POR.DRECONTENT:
Research activities. It has been understood since 18th century that motions of planets in Solar system can be described by certain equations which, due to the fact that the planets have mass significantly smaller than the Sun, are approximating very simple motion whose past and future can be completely understood. To some extent certain approximations have been understood due to great achievement from 60's which is labeled KAM theory.  In this and many other applications,  the general question is: when is it true that a close approximation of a system is dynamically the same as the original system. While in classical dynamics time is one-dimensional, in this reasearch we considered certain dynamical systems with multidimensional time.   Main research result  is extension of the classical KAM-type result for certain one-dimensional time systems on the torus, to multidimensional time systems on 2-step nilmanifolds - objects which can be viewed as extensions of the torus. With collaborators, we also show that certain mutidimensional time systems which have the special property that all orbits fill up the space, do not exist in algebraic setting, except on nilmanifolds where the above mentioned KAM-type rigidity result holds. It is precisely the algebraic  setting which often appears in applications. Support from the grant allowed me to have several meetings with collaborators, and also to present my findings at seminars and dynamical systems workshops in US and abroad.  Support from the grant has also been used for organization of two meetings which took place at Rice university:

Rice dynamics meetings May 3-5, 2013: http://math.rice.edu/NewsEvents/Conferences/Dynamics2013/index.html

Rice dynamics meetings April 26 - 28, 2014 http://math.rice.edu/NewsEvents/Conferences/Dynamics2014/index.html

At these meetings top researchers in the field of Dynamical systems presented their findings, and attendence of graduate students and women was especially encouraged and fully financially supported. At the first meeting there were 42 registered participants and  at the second meeting there were 31 participants. Approximately 30% of participants were graduate students. Approximately 25% of speakers were women.  

Educational activities.  The main part of educational activities under this grant was the outreach program for Houston high school female students, with different social and ethnic background. The class of 20 girls was formed after the  recruitment process. There were weekly meetings which lasted 1h 30min and which involved lectures and discussions. Once a month there were guest lectures  by successful women in the fields where mathematics has its application. The details of the program can be found here http://www.math.rice.edu/CHAOS/index.html. In the final phase of the program, the girls separated into groups and  worked on group projects, which they presented in a closed session at the Rice dynamics meetings on May 5, 2013. The projects were diverse, ranging from fractals, chaos in arts and literature, studying entropy and mixing in different contexts, to lives and achievements of famous women mathematicians. Participants of the program had a special discussion session with  women mathematicians who gave talks at Rice dynamics meetings. The discussion involved topics such as: how to become a mathematician, what a mathematician can do outside of academia, how is life in academia, what it takes for a women to have a successful career in science, etc. Rice graduate students and one post-doctoral student were involved in the program and this vertical integration was important as all parties involved benefitted advancing their knowledge, as well as teaching and general educational skills.
